awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Automatically Identifying Botnet Command and Control Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Unfortunately, cyber crime has become a business today. In contrast to the Internet security situation ten years ago, most of the significant Internet attacks today aim to make a financial profit. A popular and effective choice of criminals today for sending spam, stealing data, and launching attacks are so called bots -- a type of malware that is written with the intent of compromising and taking control of hosts on the Internet. The main distinguishing characteristic of a bot compared to other types of malware is that a bot is able to establish a command and control (C&C) channel.

The goal of this project is to develop novel techniques and tools to detect malicious connections from compromised machines to the C&C servers of botnets. The key insight is that when looking at very large volumes of netflow and DNS data over an extended period of time, connection attempts to benign and malicious addresses should exhibit enough differences in behavior so that they can be automatically distinguished.  A key challenge in this project is to identify behavioral features that will allow the detection of connections that exhibit botnet-like behavior.

The ability to identify malicious C&C connections and to potentially block and disrupt the communication of the attackers with their bots presents rich opportunities for industrial and societal impact. Furthermore, the research will have a broad effect though education and outreach. The PI will seek broad dissemination of research results through both top publications and industry connections.

por.por_cntn:
As the popularity of the Internet increases, so does the number of attackers whoabuse the Internet for their malicious purposes.  Unfortunately, cyber crime hasbecome a business today. In contrast to the Internet security situation tenyears ago, most of the significant Internet attacks today (e.g., Trojan horses,phishing campaigns, etc.) aim to make a financial profit. A popular andeffective choice of criminals today for sending spam, stealing data, andlaunching attacks are so called bots. A bot is a type of malware that is writtenwith the intent of compromising and taking control of hosts on the Internet. Itis typically installed on the victim's computer by either exploiting a softwarevulnerability in the web browser or the operating system, or by using socialengineering techniques to trick the victim into installing the bot herself. Themain distinguishing characteristic of a bot compared to other types of malwareis that a bot is able to establish a command and control (C&C) channel. Usingthis remote channel, an attacker can control, or update a compromised machine.
The goal of the proposed research was to develop novel techniques and tools todetect malicious connections from compromised machines to the C&C servers ofbotnets. To this end, a prototype system called DISCLOSURE was developed.The key insight is that when looking at very large volumes of netflow and DNSdata over an extended period of time, connection attempts to benign andmalicious addresses should exhibit enough differences in behavior so that theycan be automatically distinguished (e.g., such as a group of compromisedmachines regularly connecting to an ADSL box in a foreign country, and opening ahigh number of port 25 connections for sending spam).
We carried out work over the course of the project to better understand thebehavior of malicious software such as botnets.  We made significant progress inthis area, and published a well-known paper on DISCLOSURE at ACSAC 2012 that wasspecifically built on the ideas that we had promised in this project. Throughoutthe rest of the project, we continued to research and publish work in thegeneral research area of malware detection.
The research results produced in this project have significantly advanced ourunderstanding of the botnet landscape. We have built tools that are able toeffectively detect botnet command and control channels, and that can detectmalware in general.
The results produced by our previous project EXPOSURE, and some of the findingsby DISCLOSURE are used by security professionals on a daily basis to aid theiranalysis of malicious domains and command and control connections. Hence, wehave contributed to making the Internet a safer place for everyone.

Modified by: Engin Kirda
